title: Friday, 7th April, 2017

Allied Minds PLC (ALM:LSE): Last: 172.00, down 3 (-1.71%), High: 179.90, Low: 168.60, Volume: 494.63k
11:15 am
PM11:16am

We'll just keep a weather eye on that going forward

undefined
BE11:16am

Elsewhere, we have Ocado.

11:16 am
Ocado Group PLC (OCDO:LSE): Last: 240.10, down 11.9 (-4.72%), High: 243.80, Low: 233.70, Volume: 2.11m
PM11:16am

Ouch

BE11:16am

Big sector note from UBS.

11:16 am
BE11:17am

Evidence Thing. And a good read.

BE11:17am

They like Sainsbury and Tesco.

BE11:18am

But with Ocado, it's expanding into a slowing market and needs to spend big to fill the capacity, meaning forecasts look unachievable.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

Sector view first, in the form of the pivotal questions.

BE11:19am

We are positive on the UK Food Retail sector. We See market growth outpacing new space roughly 2:1 in coming years, and UK sales densities improving +1 to 1.5%/annum as a result, recovering previous high-watermarks of c.£7,100/m2 by 2020E and helping restore the industry's depressed profit pool. Market share losses to the discounters are slowing, as mainstream retailers (especially Tesco) offer improved value for money. We see increased competition from Asda as slow-burn and see no signs of disruptive price investments. We expect food inflation to be passed on from retailers to consumers up to a level of around 5%.

PM11:19am

This is a new take on their Q&A format??

11:19 am
PM11:19am

Hang on the pivotal questions for on for 50 pages!

PM11:19am

That is not ML friendly

BE11:19am

This is the exec summary section of their Q&A format, which takes the form of rhetorical questions. And to be fair, there are only two pages of them.

11:19 am
PM11:20am

ok

PM11:20am

fair enough

BE11:20am

The most interesting of which are ...................

11:20 am
BE11:20am

Will Amazon take meaningful market share in UK grocery?

BE11:21am

Mostly no, but maybe.

BE11:21am

We see the competitive threat playing out more gradually and impacting consumables more than fresh. Selling food online is more expensive than via a supermarket. That's important. Customers will not start buying online because a new entrant offers it. We actually see the online grocery market moving to maturity more quickly than the market realises. Last year online grocery growth fell to 7%, nearly half the 13% seen in the prior year. Penetration rates are plateauing. Amazon looks to be targeting a very specific customer group – its Prime customers. Usage costs for Amazon Fresh are relatively high as Fresh shoppers also have to be members of Prime. (£15/month). This immediately positions it as a niche player, since spending as little as possible is the primary driver of UK grocery shoppers. We could be wrong. If Amazon does grow market share quickly, UBS Evidence Lab data shows 97% of Ocado customers are also Amazon shoppers. Of the Big-4 Sainsbury's has the highest cross-over in terms of shopper base and store estate.

11:21 am
BE11:22am

Is Asda going to go disruptive on pricing?

BE11:22am

Mostly no, but maybe.

BE11:22am

We would not assume Asda is likely to lose another 200bps of market share in the next two years; but with consumers' brand and price perceptions still seemingly deteriorating, recovery could be a slow-burn. Our recent UBS Evidence Lab survey shows Asda customers to be the least satisfied with their experience of UK grocers. Moreover, our price monitor shows its investments have so far failed to re-establish the historical price advantages it enjoyed. Management hopes to restore a 10% price corridor vs. its 'Big-4' competitors – presumably the magic level at which it expects footfall trends to improve. Our UBS Evidence Lab Grocery Basket showed it 5.8% cheaper in 2016, but with no material improvement or deterioration in recent months. In the scenario of a turnaround, we would see Aldi and Morrisons as Asda's most direct competitors.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

And most importantly, is the sector decent value?

BE11:23am

Mostly yes, but in some parts no.

BE11:23am

Forward trading multiples do not look obviously 'cheap'. The sector currently trades on a P/E multiple of 17x – a 24% premium to the 5-year average and a 21% premium to the wider market. But with the industry still in recovery mode a premium to is appropriate. Reverse-engineering share prices using our DCF models we estimate the market is pricing in a recovered sector EBIT margins of c.3.1%, which is c.40-50% below previous industry high water marks, i.e an industry average of c.3.1% - only slightly above last year's outturn of 2.9%. We think closer to 50-100bps further improvement can be achieved. Certain changes in the industry and consumer are structural and have impaired long-term profitability. Hypermarkets footfall trends are unlikely to improve materially. Discounters Aldi and Lidl are well established and have redefined 'value' for many consumers. And e-Commerce has created price transparency across all categories. But self-help opportunities exist that can offset these headwinds in the medium-term and the market may be underestimating the linkage between sales densities and margins. In aggregate our sector medium-term sector EBIT forecast is 10-15% above consensus.

11:23 am
Tesco PLC (TSCO:LSE): Last: 187.70, up 2.5 (+1.35%), High: 189.60, Low: 185.30, Volume: 9.95m
J Sainsbury PLC (SBRY:LSE): Last: 258.40, up 4 (+1.57%), High: 259.60, Low: 257.20, Volume: 2.09m
WM Morrison Supermarkets PLC (MRW:LSE): Last: 232.90, up 2.2 (+0.95%), High: 233.80, Low: 230.30, Volume: 1.91m
11:24 am
BE11:24am

....... but returning to Ocado.

PM11:25am

Just leafing through this note -- 84 pages of incredible detail. Bt sorry, Ocado....

BE11:26am

As I say, it's a good bit of work. I like the UBS evidence lab pieces.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

Here's the breakout note on Ocado

BE11:26am

We think meeting both consensus revenue and margin expectations will be tough for Ocado. Technology leadership has seen Ocado evolve best-in-class operational efficiency, reducing the cost of online grocery to profitable levels and underpinning a superior customer offer. We believe its flagship customer fulfilment centre (CFC) in Erith, opening 2018, could generate an impressive 22% IRR and has potential to drive earnings and a cashflow inflection. However, we believe the market is moving against Ocado, presenting roadblocks to such a scenario. Growth rates in online grocery have slowed markedly (just when Ocado is bringing new capacity to market), and we think it may struggle to maintain price competiveness in an inflationary environment. We see this as a tough juggling act, and assume coverage with a Sell rating.

BE11:27am

UBS Evidence Lab survey data indicates online grocery growth halved to c.7% in 2016, and suggests penetration rates are starting to plateau. Ocado roughly doubles its CFC capacity to 615,000 OPW (orders per week) over 2016-18E, significantly outpacing addressable market growth. It has flexibility in the rate it adds modules, but consensus implies a fairly uninterrupted ramp-up. To reach scale it will need to acquire customers through price and marketing investments.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

In our view, Ocado's limited purchasing power suggests it will struggle to maintain both gross margin and price competitiveness in an inflationary environment. Its Low Price Promise (LPP) sees it price-match market-leader Tesco on everyday items. Tesco is reinvesting volume gains and has committed to shield customers as far as possible from inflation. This, combined with, we assume, weaker terms of trade at Ocado (similar to Waitrose), could see LPP become a burden. The UBS Evidence Lab Grocery Pricing Monitor shows Tesco's basket +1.2% YoY; Ocado's +1.8% and Waitrose's +4.4%.

BE11:27am

With this assumption of coverage, we assign a Sell rating (previously Buy) and 200p price target (previously 425p). We approach our valuation using standalone DCF models for each CFC, to enable a sum of the parts. Our NAV is £1.72/sh (9% WACC), implying c.£500m in the price for future Ocado Smart Platform deals. We expect partnerships to be worth in the tens rather than hundreds of millions.

BE11:28am

....... and that's a lot of UBS. Daniel Ekstein's the analyst.

11:28 am
PM11:28am

Thumbs up

BE11:29am

It's just occurred that Ocado's an interesting case in unicorn-ness. It was invented for the future we believed in 15 years ago.

BE11:29am

11:29 am

PM11:30am

11:30 am
BE11:30am

PM11:35am

The compound annual growth rate (CAGR) was calculated as follows:

((revenue2015 / revenue2012 )^(1/3)) - 1 = CAGR

The absolute growth between 2012 and 2015 was calculated as follows:

(revenue2015 / revenue2012 ) - 1 = Growth rate

11:38 am
PM11:38am

BE11:38am

Someone -- was it RBC? -- was pushing Aberdeen.

Aberdeen Asset Management PLC (ADN:LSE): Last: 274.40, up 7.1 (+2.66%), High: 275.90, Low: 269.00, Volume: 2.67m
11:38 am
BE11:39am

We're all too negative about its rubbish merger, is the thesis.

BE11:39am

PM11:39am

Ah, I like Peter's stuff

11:39 am
BE11:39am

Our view: EPS forecasts increased by 8%/9%/3% in FY17E/18E/19E because of strong investment performance. Investors are positively exposed to income, value and upside risk. We maintain our 300p price target (despite higher forecasts) and upgrade to Outperform.

PM11:39am

But I seem to have fallen off his distribution list.

BE11:40am

I'm still on it, I think. You must have offended the Canadians.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

Which takes some doing.

BE11:40am

Price target maintained at 300p, but valuation approach changes. To value Aberdeen we now take an average of the three valuation methods (fundamentals-based standalone valuation, "look through" valuation of the merged company, merger terms valuation based upon RBC's price target for Standard Life), which yields a rounded price target of 300p. While our 300p price target somewhat disagrees with the valuation method of applying the merger terms to the RBC Standard Life price target, we note that our Standard Life price target does not give Standard Life any benefit for its considerable surplus capital position.

BE11:41am

We believe risk is to the upside and the shares have over-reacted on the downside. The key negative – ongoing net outflows at both companies – is well known and more than reflected in the share price, while the defensive nature of the merger and potential disruption to the businesses as they integrate is fully understood, in our opinion. The resulting company will have greater scale in addition to distribution opportunities and cost savings (it is our opinion that cost savings could be as much as 50% higher than the stated figure of £200MM). Aberdeen offers ongoing cost control, inflecting net flows, a stable revenue margin, and decent underlying investment performance. At the current level, we believe Aberdeen is attractive to both value and income-orientated investors. While the market generally acknowledges the long-term benefits (despite being defensive in nature) from asset manager consolidation, the share price performances of both Aberdeen and Standard Life since the merger announcement has been dictated by the short-term considerations. As a result, while we maintain our 300p price target (despite higher forecasts), we upgrade Aberdeen to Outperform.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

11:43 am
PM11:44am

See this Worldspreads stuff?

BE11:44am

PM11:44am

Do you remember that going down

11:44 am
BE11:44am

PM11:44am

The Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has banned and imposed financial penalties on two former Worldspreads Limited (WSL) employees. WSL, which operated a spread betting business, collapsed in March 2012.

The FCA has fined WSL’s former Chief Financial Officer, Niall O’Kelly, £11,900 and former Financial Controller, Lukhvir Thind, £105,000, for engaging in market abuse and permanently banned them both from performing any function related to regulated activity.

In August 2007, the holding company of WSL, Worldspreads Group (WSG), floated on the Alternative Investment Market of the London Stock Exchange. Mr O’Kelly was closely involved in drafting and approving the admission documentation for the flotation, which contained materially misleading information and omitted key information that investors would have needed in order to make an informed decision about the company.

The FCA also found that Mr O’Kelly helped manage an undisclosed ‘internal hedging’ strategy at WSL using fake client trading accounts and the unauthorised use of actual client trading accounts. By doing this, he artificially inflated assets on WSG’s balance sheet.

In the Annual Accounts for 2010 and 2011, Mr O’Kelly and Mr Thind knowingly falsified critical financial information concerning WSL’s client liabilities and its cash position, which was passed to the company’s auditors. This meant that material shortfalls in WSL’s client money position were concealed from investors. By 31 March 2011, these misstatements amounted to £15.9 million. WSL was unable to meet this client money liability which ultimately led to WSL’s collapse in 2012.

PM11:45am

11:57 am
PM11:57am

Just having a trawl round so if there's anything to wrap up with

BE11:57am

Someone mentioned Next earlier.

Next PLC (NXT:LSE): Last: 3,999, down 43 (-1.06%), High: 4,023, Low: 3,968, Volume: 282.85k
11:57 am
BE11:57am

Which is Canaccord selling.

BE11:58am

Next's business model may not be broken, but signs of stress fractures have appeared in the recent past. No longer the best in class operator in omni-channel retailing, Next has moved down the competitive pecking order, and is having to invest in catch-up spending and development. This pressure has been compounded by an inflection point in its most profitable Credit customer base. These concerns are well known to the market.
We have other less widely appreciated concerns. First, Next appears to be ageing with its customer base, rather than maintaining its core target customer demographic. This is rightly seen as a slippery path for any retailer, resulting in extremis in Mutually Assured Destruction, since its customer base literally dies out over time. Next seems aware of this c. 20% shift from its heartland 25 - 44 age demographic to the 45+ age group. Second, we calculate that the proportion of discounted Brand sales has been trending upwards since FY14, with a CAGR of c 10%, over 3x the growth rate of Full Price sales. Unless these are addressed and reversed, we fear further bottom line pressure over time.
We also analyse Next's stress test of its Retail portfolio. We are less sanguine on Next's contention that it will remain a "valuable asset" in 10 years' time, especially in the -6% LFL scenario. In the probable event of a less than 100% sales transfer from closed stores to Directory, it places a significant onus on Directory to make organic market share gains to offset the significant contribution shortfall (£190-440m) implied by the stress test.

BE11:58am

The shares rallied initially after the prelims on the basis that unchanged guidance equates to no new bad news. This is open to debate in our view, with Next's latest operational slip on heartland product - compounding last year's stock availability issue in Directory - pointing to an increasingly accident-prone business, certainly relative to the historic view of Next as an exemplar of operational excellence. This may seem harsh in the absence of a profit collapse, but it is nonetheless a worrying blip, if not an embedded trend. Forward profit expectations for FY18E are now c.£200m (22%) lower at the mid-range point of £730m than going into Next's Christmas trading update in January 2016. Given our further minor PBT forecast cuts for FY18 and FY19, the apposite question is what is the correct rating for a cash generative but potentially ex-growth company?

11:58 am
BE11:58am

The all-in yield of c.8% is the stock's major support, but the earnings trajectory remains weak. We move to a DCF methodology to better address longer-term fundamental concerns. Our core assumptions of a 16% terminal EBIT margin and 9.0x terminal EV/EBIT drive our new TP of 3714p (was 4400p), and we cut to SELL (from Hold).

BE11:59am

All of which feels quite familiar, in terms of arguments, though on the more bearish end of the spectrum.
